awd_titl_txt: The Trace Formula Method and the Arithmetic and Geometry of Modular Varieties in the Langlands Program
awd_abstract_narration:
Number theory is one of the oldest branches of mathematics. It studies properties of the integers. The impact of research in number theory on modern science and technology is significant. Most notably, number theory has proved indispensable in cryptography, internet security, telecommunication, and so on. This is a project to study the so-called Langlands program, which predicts deep relations between number theory and other seemingly unrelated branches of mathematics. Progress in the Langlands program will not only advance our knowledge in number theory, but also demonstrate the unification of mathematics, showing that seemingly different areas in mathematics are governed by certain common principles. This will be beneficial for enhancing communication and collaboration between researchers working in different branches of mathematics and will have potential applications to cryptography, internet security, telecommunication, and so on, as mentioned above.

In more detail, a central topic in the Langlands program is the reciprocity between motives and automorphic forms. One of the most important tools is the trace formula. In the context of automorphic forms, there are trace formulas of Arthur-Selberg type and the so-called relative trace formulas. In the context of  algebraic geometry, there are trace formulas of Grothendieck-Lefschetz-Verdier type. The investigator studies these trace formulas in conjunction with various geometric objects that naturally arise in the Langlands program. These geometric objects, which include Shimura varieties, moduli spaces of shtukas, Rapoport-Zink spaces, affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties, etc., are themselves moduli spaces of certain geometric structures. The goal of this project is to describe, in various concrete settings, the interaction between trace formulas and the arithmetic and geometry of these moduli spaces. Such an understanding will lead to results on the relation between motives and automorphic forms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project is in the area of the Langlands Program, which is a confluence of number theory and representation theory. Number theory is the study of properties of whole numbers. This is one of the oldest areas in mathematics, and has throughout history been a driving force of the development of many other areas in pure mathematics and applied mathematics (such as cryptography) alike. A typical question in number theory is finding the number of solutions of a given equation system in whole numbers or related number systems.  Representation theory, on the other hand, is the study of objects with symmetry. The kind of representation theory that goes into the Langlands Program is also closely related to harmonic analysis, that is, the study of how one can decompose a "spectrum'' in various contexts, the root of which is the classical problem of decomposing complicated waves into simpler ones such as the sinusoidal waves.

The Langlands program decipcts a conjectural mapping between the world of number theory and the world of representation theory, two worlds that are a priori remote from each other. A lot of such conjectural predictions have been verified in the previous decades, resulting in major achievements such as the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, but much more remains to be explored.

One key feature in the Langlands Program is the prediction that automorphic L-functions, which are certain functions arising in representation theory, are closely related to motivic L-functions, which arise in number theory. An example is the famous Riemann zeta function, which belongs to the two categories simultaneously.To understand such relationship, Langlands proposed the approach of comparing the trace formula, which is a tool in harmonic analysis, with data that come from number theory. A testing ground for this approach is the study of the motivic L-function of Shimura vareities, which are geometric spaces at the crossroad of number theory, Lie theory, and differential geometry. 

One of the main outcomes of this award is the proof, jointly with M. Kisin and S. W. Shin, of the conjecture of Langlands and Kottwitz relating the motivic L-function of a Shimura variety to the Arthur-Selberg stable trace formulas, in the case of Shimura varieties of abelian type. This result will serve as the main techinal tool for further research into the relationship between the motivic L-function of Shimura varieties and automorphic L-functions. In the special cases of unitary and orthogonal Shimura varieties, there are already applications of this result to the determination of the motivic L-function as an explicit product of automorphic L-functions. The unitary case, in particular, serves as an important input to the study of Bloch-Kato conjectures and Gross-Zagier-type formulas by Wei Zhang et al.  

Another outcome of the award is the determination of certain geometric features of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties. Affine Deligne Lusztig varieties are like Shimura varieties in that they are geometric spaces defined by polynomial equations, but unlike Shimura varieties they only live over mod-p number systems, that is, number systems that reflect the congruence of integers modulo a chosen prime number p. These spaces are designed to aid the study of the mod-p geometry of Shimura varieties, and they also enter the work described in the preceding paragraph. In joint works with R. Zhou and with X. He and R. Zhou, we determine the number of irreducible components of affine Deligne-Lusztig varieties, as well as the number of irreducible components of the "basic locus" of a Shimura variety. Roughly, these numbers indicate how the relevant geometric spaces are composed of smaller building blocks. Our approach is to use trace formula methods in order to turn the geometric question into a question in representation theory, and to attack the latter by combinatorial means. Apart from the interest of the result itself, our method of proof sheds light on how purely representation-theoretic and combinatorial considerations can be applied to study problems in arithmetic geometry. This will hopefully inspire new ties between these subjects in future research.
